articles.headline: How G.M. Tricked Millions of Drivers Into Being Spied On (Including Me)
articles.snippet: This privacy reporter and her husband bought a Chevrolet Bolt in December. Two risk-profiling companies had been getting detailed data about their driving ever since.
articles.abstract: This privacy reporter and her husband bought a Chevrolet Bolt in December. Two risk-profiling companies had been getting detailed data about their driving ever since.
articles.lead_paragraph: Automakers have been selling data about the driving behavior of millions of people to the insurance industry. In the case of General Motors, affected drivers weren’t informed, and the tracking led insurance companies to charge some of them more for premiums. I’m the reporter who broke the story. I recently discovered that I’m among the drivers who was spied on.

articles.headline: Who Can Be Trusted for Retirement Advice? New Rules Strengthen Protections.
articles.snippet: More investment professionals will be required to act in their customers’ best interest when providing advice about their retirement money.
articles.abstract: More investment professionals will be required to act in their customers’ best interest when providing advice about their retirement money.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you walk into a financial adviser’s office, you expect them to put your best interests above all else — in the same way a doctor would, rather than, say, a car salesman. But many people don’t realize that the rules financial professionals must follow vary, depending on where they work and what products they’re selling.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Issues Ban on Worker Noncompete Clauses
articles.snippet: The rule would prohibit companies from limiting their employees’ ability to work for rivals, a change that could increase competition and boost wages.
articles.abstract: The rule would prohibit companies from limiting their employees’ ability to work for rivals, a change that could increase competition and boost wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday said employers could no longer, in most cases, stop their employees from going to work for rival companies.

articles.headline: ‘It Is Desolate’: China’s Glut of Unused Car Factories
articles.snippet: Manufacturers like BYD, Tesla and Li Auto are cutting prices to move their electric cars. For gasoline-powered vehicles, the surplus of factories is even worse.
articles.abstract: Manufacturers like BYD, Tesla and Li Auto are cutting prices to move their electric cars. For gasoline-powered vehicles, the surplus of factories is even worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the outskirts of Chongqing, western China’s largest city, sits a huge symbol of the country’s glut of car factories. It’s a complex of gray buildings, nearly a square mile in size. The thousands of employees who used to work there have moved on. Its crimson loading docks are closed.

articles.headline: Former Boeing Manager Says Workers Mishandled Parts to Meet Deadlines
articles.snippet: Merle Meyers, who left Boeing last year after a 30-year career, said he was speaking publicly about his experience because he loved the company “fiercely.”
articles.abstract: Merle Meyers, who left Boeing last year after a 30-year career, said he was speaking publicly about his experience because he loved the company “fiercely.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Two framed documents from a long career at Boeing hang side by side in Merle Meyers’s home: A certificate from 2022 that thanks him for three decades of service. And a letter he received months later reprimanding him for his performance.

articles.headline: ‘Kharkiv Is Unbreakable’: A Battered City Carries On
articles.snippet: For residents of Ukraine’s second-largest city, daily Russian attacks have escalated fears but have not brought life to a standstill.
articles.abstract: For residents of Ukraine’s second-largest city, daily Russian attacks have escalated fears but have not brought life to a standstill.
articles.lead_paragraph: The espresso machine was warming up and Liliia Korneva was counting cash at the coffee shop in Kharkiv where she works when a powerful Russian bomb detonated nearby, sending up a deafening explosion and knocking her to the floor.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: Supreme Court Appears Sharply Divided in Emergency Abortion Case
articles.snippet: The justices weighed whether a federal law aimed at protecting access to emergency medical care superseded Idaho’s near-total abortion ban.
articles.abstract: The justices weighed whether a federal law aimed at protecting access to emergency medical care superseded Idaho’s near-total abortion ban.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court appeared sharply divided on Wednesday over whether federal law should allow doctors to perform emergency abortions in states with near-total bans on the procedure, in a case that could determine access to abortion in emergency rooms across the country.

articles.headline: High Borrowing Costs Have Some Democrats Urging Biden to Pressure the Fed
articles.snippet: Polls show voters are angry about costs, like mortgages, and worried they will stay high if the president wins re-election.
articles.abstract: Polls show voters are angry about costs, like mortgages, and worried they will stay high if the president wins re-election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sky-high mortgage rates and other elevated borrowing costs are pinching American consumers ahead of the 2024 election, threatening President Biden’s chances at a second term.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Meta’s A.I. Assistant Is Fun to Use, but It Can’t Be Trusted
articles.snippet: Despite Mark Zuckerberg’s hope for the chatbot to be the smartest, it struggles with facts, numbers and web search.
articles.abstract: Despite Mark Zuckerberg’s hope for the chatbot to be the smartest, it struggles with facts, numbers and web search.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last few days, you may have noticed something new inside Meta’s apps, including Instagram, Messenger and WhatsApp: an artificially intelligent chatbot.

articles.headline: Boeing Loses $355 Million in Latest Quarter
articles.snippet: The manufacturer has had to slow production of its popular 737 Max planes after a hole blew open on a jet during an Alaska Airlines flight in January.
articles.abstract: The manufacturer has had to slow production of its popular 737 Max planes after a hole blew open on a jet during an Alaska Airlines flight in January.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing on Wednesday reported a $355 million loss for the first three months of the year, as it deals with a quality crisis stemming from a Jan. 5 flight during which a panel blew off one of its planes.

articles.headline: ‘It’s Just Agony’: A Suburban Family Mourns Nearly 200 Gaza Relatives
articles.snippet: Adam and Ola Abo Sheriah absorb a loss few of their friends and neighbors in New Jersey can imagine, and scramble to help surviving family members in Gaza while trying to get their kids to school on time.
articles.abstract: Adam and Ola Abo Sheriah absorb a loss few of their friends and neighbors in New Jersey can imagine, and scramble to help surviving family members in Gaza while trying to get their kids to school on time.
articles.lead_paragraph: The call came in around 4 p.m., while Adam Abo Sheriah was still at work in his pharmacy in New Jersey.  The voice on the other end was sobbing.
articles.byline: By Anna Betts, Nada Rashwan and Amir Hamja

articles.headline: Business Groups Sue to Stop F.T.C. From Banning Noncompete Clauses
articles.snippet: The lawsuits contend the F.T.C. does not have the authority to prohibit companies from limiting their employees’ ability to work for rivals.
articles.abstract: The lawsuits contend the F.T.C. does not have the authority to prohibit companies from limiting their employees’ ability to work for rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce fulfilled its promise to sue the Federal Trade Commission over a ban on agreements that prevent workers from leaving a company for a rival, arguing in a lawsuit filed Wednesday that the agency overstepped its authority.
